verses.text: Hear this, all you peoples; listen, all who live in this world,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 49 This psalm is in the wisdom tradition (vv. 3, 4), treating issues typical of the wisdom books. The psalmist wrestles with two problems: death and the prosperity of the rich. The psalm is one of the most difficult to translate and interpret correctly. Few places in the Old Testament express so directly the hope for the resurrection of the dead. The full doctrine of the resurrection was not revealed until Jesus rose from the grave and ascended to the right hand of God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:1
rsbNotes.text: 49:1 all peoples. The psalm applies not only to people in redemptive relationship with God, but to all people everywhere.

verses.text: both low and high, rich and poor alike:

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:2
rsbNotes.text: 49:2 rich and poor. The psalmist is disturbed by the complacency of the rich.

verses.text: My mouth will speak words of wisdom; the utterance from my heart will give understanding.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:3
rsbNotes.text: 49:3 speak wisdom. The psalm will provide practical insight on the problem at hand. The psalmist identifies himself with the sages of Israel.

verses.text: I will turn my ear to a proverb; with the harp I will expound my riddle:

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:4
rsbNotes.text: 49:4 proverb . . . riddle. These words locate the psalm in the wisdom tradition.

verses.text: Why should I fear when evil days come, when wicked deceivers surround me-

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:5
rsbNotes.text: 49:5 times of trouble. These are the days approaching one’s death (cf. Eccl. 12:1).

verses.text: those who trust in their wealth and boast of their great riches?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:6
rsbNotes.text: 49:6 trust in their wealth. Rather than trusting God.

verses.text: No man can redeem the life of another or give to God a ransom for him-
the ransom for a life is costly, no payment is ever enough-
that he should live on forever and not see decay.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:7
rsbNotes.text: 49:7 no man can ransom another. No amount of money can prevent death, and no one can escape his or her obligation to die.

verses.text: For all can see that wise men die; the foolish and the senseless alike perish and leave their wealth to others.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:10
rsbNotes.text: 49:10 the wise die; the fool. The thought is reminiscent of Eccl. 2:12–16. The psalmist classifies the rich oppressor with the fools and the senseless.

verses.text: Their tombs will remain their houses forever, their dwellings for endless generations, though they had named lands after themselves.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:11
rsbNotes.text: 49:11 their dwelling places to all generations. The rich spend much of their lifetime building earthly homes and amassing wealth. But all these things soon pass away.

verses.text: But man, despite his riches, does not endure; he is like the beasts that perish.
This is the fate of those who trust in themselves, and of their followers, who approve their sayings. Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:12
rsbNotes.text: 49:12 he is like the beasts that perish. In comparing this experience of both humans and animals, the psalmist parallels the thought of Eccl. 3:18–21.

verses.text: Like sheep they are destined for the grave, and death will feed on them. The upright will rule over them in the morning; their forms will decay in the grave, far from their princely mansions.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:14
rsbNotes.text: 49:14 Like sheep. Unaware, the self-trusting rich are on the road to slaughter.

verses.text: But God will redeem my life from the grave; he will surely take me to himself. Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:15
rsbNotes.text: 49:15 God will ransom my soul from . . . Sheol. While God does not accept a ransom for death (v. 7), He provides one for the psalmist. The key to this Old Testament awareness of redemption from death is recognition of the eternity of God and of His eternal relationship with His people: “he will receive me.” See Mark 12:26, 27.

verses.text: Do not be overawed when a man grows rich, when the splendor of his house increases;
for he will take nothing with him when he dies, his splendor will not descend with him.
Though while he lived he counted himself blessed- and men praise you when you prosper-
he will join the generation of his fathers, who will never see the light of life.
A man who has riches without understanding is like the beasts that perish.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 49:16–20
rsbNotes.text: 49:16–20 The wicked rich cannot carry their wealth into the dark, joyless eternity to which they are appointed.
